author: Emma O'Brien
title: Futures Signal Asian Stocks to Retreat With Crude in Bear Market
text:
Index futures from Japan to Hong Kong fell, with Asian stocks headed for their third weekly drop this month, as mixed U.S. earnings and the commodities selloff fuel concern over the global outlook. Oil was below $49 a barrel.
Contracts on Japanese shares slipped at least 0.3 percent with futures on stock gauges from Hong Kong to Australia. Nasdaq 100 Index futures climbed 0.2 percent by 8:09 a.m. in Tokyo as Amazon.com Inc. soared 18 percent in extended trading after posting a surprise profit . U.S. oil traded at $48.70 after capping a 20 percent slump from its recent high last session, the definition of a bear market. Copper sank a sixth day after Goldman Sachs Group Inc. forecast further declines.
Asian stocks have paced losses in global equities this week as concern over supply gluts sent gold to industrial metals and crops tumbling. Adding to commodity investors’ pain is the resurgent dollar, with focus shifting to next week’s Federal Reserve policy meeting amid buoyant economic data. A gauge of Chinese manufacturing due Friday may confirm the sector contracted a fifth straight month in July, with similar measures for Japan, the U.S. and euro area also scheduled.
“Demand just isn’t there,” said Michael Smith, the president of T&K Futures and Options Inc. in Port St. Lucie, Florida. “Until we see a pickup in China and the other emerging economies, commodities are going to suffer, particularly copper. We’re just going to start seeing build ups in supply, globally.”
Copper, Oil Copper futures for September delivery on the Comex lost 0.4 percent to $2.3765 a pound, after touching their lowest level since July 2009 last session. Goldman said prices will drop another 15 percent by the end of the year with Chinese demand for the metal to grow at the slowest pace in almost two decades. Gold was headed for a fifth straight weekly drop, trading at $1,090.77 an ounce after two days of losses.
Signs of resilient oil output from the U.S. and an uptick in OPEC supply has hit crude, with West Texas Intermediate oil down 4.3 percent this week, its fourth straight weekly retreat. Brent sank 1.5 percent to $55.27 a barrel Thursday. The Bloomberg Commodity Index extended losses at a 13-year low last session.
While Amazon ’s results, which included better-than-estimated second-quarter sales, bolstered U.S. index futures after markets closed, it was a different picture during the normal trading day. The Standard & Poor’s 500 Index slipped 0.6 percent as materials and energy shares slumped. Disappointing earnings from Caterpillar Inc. and 3M Co. sent their stock down at least 3.6 percent.
Mixed Earnings The earnings season has been spotty for U.S. companies so far, with sluggish demand overseas damping returns for some multinational companies. Earnings per share at S&P 500 companies probably fell 5.3 percent in the second quarter, according to analysts’ estimates. Disappointing results from Apple Inc. and Microsoft Corp. earlier in the week sparked a selloff in technology shares.
In the futures market, contracts on Japan’s Nikkei 225 Stock Average dropped 0.4 percent to 20,590 in the Osaka pre-market, while yen-denominated futures were up 0.1 percent to 20,595 following three sessions of losses. The yen, which typically moves at odds with Japanese equities, has climbed 0.2 percent this week, to 123.90 per dollar.
Futures on Australia’s S&P/ASX 200 Index lost 0.3 percent amid the commodities retreat. Iron ore, the nation’s biggest export, has fallen 1.3 percent the past three days, paring its advance in the week to 2.1 percent. The S&P/ASX 200 is down 1.4 percent this week, led by raw-materials producers, energy companies and utilities.
Dollar Moves Kospi index futures in Seoul dropped 0.6 percent, while contracts on the Hang Seng Index in Hong Kong were down 0.4 percent. Futures on the Hang Seng China Enterprises Index, a gauge of mainland stocks listed in the city, slipped 0.3 percent in most recent trading. FTSE China A50 Index futures in Singapore declined 0.7 percent.
The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index has held on to its gains this week, trading close to a three-month high with bets even on whether the Fed will raise rates in September for the first time since 2006. Commodity currencies, including the Brazilian real as well as the Canadian and Australian dollars, have weakened at least 0.2 percent, while New Zealand’s dollar rallied after the central bank dropped a reference to its level being unjustified.
